clues.text: This bald "Seinfeld" character hit on a woman by saying he lived with his parents & was unemployed
Perhaps the improved aerodynamic design helped him become 1999's No. 1 ranked tennis player
This follically-challenged animated man once sold his soul to the devil for a doughnut
This Proctor & Gamble icon dresses in white, wears an earring & hates dirt
This super-rich Little Orphan Annie benefactor never joined the Hair Club for Men
She auditioned for the role of Cordelia on "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" but won the title role instead
Apparently, "What Women Want" was to vote his gams the "Sexiest Celebrity Legs" in a 2001 survey by Hanes
She probably should've had the "Basic Instinct" not to appear in "Police Academy 4"
This actor led the Soggy Bottom Boys in "O Brother, Where Art Thou?"
David Copperfield's 6-year engagement to this German supermodel disappeared in 1999
Many bridges in this Italian canal city were once privately owned & tolls were charged for their crossing
This resort area along the Mediterranean coast includes the cities of St. Tropez, France & San Remo, Italy
The main drag in this capital of French Polynesia is Boulevard Pomare, named for a Tahitian queen
The small caves in this tourist site, seen here, contain ancient rock paintings by Aboriginal artists
This "saintly" Swiss resort was the site of the Winter Olympic Games in 1928 & 1948
Protests against the Confederate flag in Columbia, this state's capital, said, "Your Heritage is my Slavery"
Signs reading "Hate is not Hip" protested this white rapper's lyrics at the Grammys in 2001
Signs at a 1998 protest called nuclear waste transport "Mobile" this Ukrainian place
Signs seen at this "world" group's 1999 meeting in Seattle included one saying it "Kills Butterflies"
Protesters against genetically modified foods insisted "Children are not" these animals of the family Caviidae
"The squeaky wheel gets the worm" is an example of a mixed one of these
When referring to the New York Mets, "Mets" is short for this
If you don't like this "American Buffalo" playwright, well, &*$% you, pal!
It's the border or outer boundary of a 2-dimensional figure
She was a goddess of agriculture in Greek mythology
This enclosure for horses or cattle was usually made of posts or poles; temporary ones were of rope
This cookhouse on wheels was said to have been invented by Charles Goodnight who modified an army wagon
Slang term for the cemetery of a western town; Dodge City's dates back to 1872
When riding a wild horse, it was a disgrace to have to "grab the apple" to stay on, the apple being this
Originally applied to a gun named for its inventor, it later became generic for small single-shot pistols
Obviously feeling no one could replace him, Fillmore never named anyone to this cabinet-level job
Under Fillmore the price of this dropped from 5 cents to 3; in 2001, it went up from 33 cents to 34
The Fillmore-approved Compromise of 1850 included admitting this "Golden State" into the Union
Don't flip out if you don't know Fillmore was the last president from this political party
Fillmore died in 1874 & was buried in this city in New York state, later the site of McKinley's assassination

In an expression possibly from Shakespeare's time, a short-lived sensation is this many "days' wonder"
In a 1960 film, this title number of crooks, led by Danny Ocean, plan a Vegas caper
Number of stars in the Big Dipper
The traditional number of those who attended the Last Supper
In 1993 this "SNL" alum returned to TV as a late-night talk show host, but lasted only 6 weeks
Protests by gay rights groups cost this radio "doctor" sponsors for her TV show
Teens & critics protested when ABC dropped this low-rated Claire Danes series midseason
In 1989 housewife Terry Rakolta tried to get advertisers & viewers to boycott this Fox sitcom
Religious groups protested this '90s drama in which Kevin Anderson played a priest dealing with sensitive issues

The walls around this Spanish city were 400 years old when St. Teresa lived there
This "stately" Confederate cruiser sank many ships before being sunk by the Kearsarge off the coast of France

rounds.text: In 1909 he completed his last painting, a canvas called "Driftwood"
